messages.message: Hey turkey. I’m just saying hi and wondering what your thoughts are on Rum and Gre? Serb is traditionally Austrian territory and Bul goes to Turkey. I’m just wondering how the Russian situation is going to shake out. Also, would you be open to sharing information you hear about me with me in exchange for Russian intel?
messages.input: My response to TURKEY:'Hey turkey. I’m just saying hi and wondering what your thoughts are on Rum and Gre? Serb is traditionally Austrian territory and Bul goes to Turkey. I’m just wondering how the Russian situation is going to shake out. Also, would you be open to sharing information you hear about me with me in exchange for Russian intel?'.

messages.message: Hi, I am willing to work with you, at least in the intel sharing part. I would be happy if we split Rum and Gre in a way that steers us away from each other.
messages.input: Message from TURKEY:'Hi, I am willing to work with you, at least in the intel sharing part. I would be happy if we split Rum and Gre in a way that steers us away from each other.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. The response from TURKEY shows a willingness to cooperate and share information, aligning with your initial outreach and suggesting a potential for collaboration in the game.

messages.message: I can’t speak to the split now, but if we do split it me Gre you Rum, I propose that you only put Fleets in Rum and I only put armies in Greece. If you’d rather I put a fleet in that’s OK too
messages.input: My response to TURKEY:'I can’t speak to the split now, but if we do split it me Gre you Rum, I propose that you only put Fleets in Rum and I only put armies in Greece. If you’d rather I put a fleet in that’s OK too'.

messages.message: That is reasonable but then that would mean you and Italy fight while it is me against Russia. What about a reverse? I get Gre? Would that work for you at all?
messages.input: Message from TURKEY:'That is reasonable but then that would mean you and Italy fight while it is me against Russia. What about a reverse? I get Gre? Would that work for you at all?'.
messages.output: You should not trust the message. TURKEY's suggestion to change the agreed upon split and take Greece instead raises concerns about their commitment to the initial plan, potentially indicating a shift in their intentions that may not align with your best interests.

messages.message: Why does being in Greece commit me to the Italian front? Galicia is crucial to taking Russia.
messages.input: My response to TURKEY:'Why does being in Greece commit me to the Italian front? Galicia is crucial to taking Russia.'.

messages.message: Because what will italy do in that case? He is the eastern power and he will definitely be looking for greece for himself. Also if you take greece and then commit to fight russia, ehat do i get from that? You got easy greece for you while I have to fight for everything. Hopefully you understand my point here.
messages.input: Message from TURKEY:'Because what will italy do in that case? He is the eastern power and he will definitely be looking for greece for himself. Also if you take greece and then commit to fight russia, ehat do i get from that? You got easy greece for you while I have to fight for everything. Hopefully you understand my point here.'.
messages.output: You should not trust the message. TURKEY's argument about the implications of controlling Greece and potential consequences for your position with Italy and Russia raises doubts about their intentions and suggests a possible attempt to manipulate the situation to their advantage.

messages.message: That’s fair. It’ll also make more sense for me to not mess around in Greece and build an army while you focus navy. If we structure our build types well, we can keep the relationship fairly balanced. I think I might be able to sneak some Italian gains early on and am considering moving that direction if Russia stays out of Gal in 1901. If it works, you won’t have to worry about a Lepanto.
messages.input: My response to TURKEY:'That’s fair. It’ll also make more sense for me to not mess around in Greece and build an army while you focus navy. If we structure our build types well, we can keep the relationship fairly balanced. I think I might be able to sneak some Italian gains early on and am considering moving that direction if Russia stays out of Gal in 1901. If it works, you won’t have to worry about a Lepanto.'.

messages.message: Okay, how this might go then if Russia enters Galicia? That could be a trouble for you and trouble for me
messages.input: Message from TURKEY:'Okay, how this might go then if Russia enters Galicia? That could be a trouble for you and trouble for me'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. TURKEY's concern about the possible escalation of conflict if Russia enters Galicia reflects a shared interest in maintaining stability and suggests a genuine consideration of the potential challenges that may arise in the game.

messages.message: I don’t think that’s going to happen. If it does, I’ll be able to survive long enough for England, you, or Germany to distract him. You could always open to Armenia?
messages.input: My response to TURKEY:'I don’t think that’s going to happen. If it does, I’ll be able to survive long enough for England, you, or Germany to distract him. You could always open to Armenia?'.

messages.message: I’m moving my fleet to Alb not for Greece but for Italy. Just a heads up
messages.input: My response to TURKEY:'I’m moving my fleet to Alb not for Greece but for Italy. Just a heads up'.

messages.message: Russia has indicated that he is not going to move F Sev - Rum. Just letting a friend know so that you can bounce him.
messages.input: My response to TURKEY:'Russia has indicated that he is not going to move F Sev - Rum. Just letting a friend know so that you can bounce him.'.

messages.message: Okay I will go for Rum, but he is probably going to support himself there, so I reckon Galicia is safe.
messages.input: Message from TURKEY:'Okay I will go for Rum, but he is probably going to support himself there, so I reckon Galicia is safe.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. TURKEY's consideration of Russia potentially supporting themselves in Rum and the implication that Galicia is safe suggests a strategic analysis of the situation and a shared interest in coordinating moves effectively.

messages.message: You’re not going to take Greece this turn?
messages.input: My response to TURKEY:'You’re not going to take Greece this turn?'.

messages.message: Seriously, both of us are getting screwed by our "allies". Former allies. Why do you continue to fight me?
